author: m.kalinin
content: Epoch can be recovered from the slot but in general case you may not have access to a chain to recover the checkpoint root from the head root

author: potuz
content: If you don't have the head root then you can't even import the attestation

author: m.kalinin
content: you don't need to import the attestations to produce attester slashing

author: potuz
content: Oh you mean to slash where you don't know one of the branches?

author: m.kalinin
content: yes, produce slashing and then process it

author: m.kalinin
content: I believe we can remove `epoch` from target checkpoint, this is because we can assume that slots per epoch will never change in the existing protocol. Or if they change `epoch` can be easily recoverable anyway

author: potuz
content: Do you need the checkpoint for slashings? Both double votes and surroundings can be checked with the slot and blockroot

author: m.kalinin
content: you're right, blockroot can replace checkpoint root

author: m.kalinin
content: an important property is that checkpoint root implies a certain blockroot

author: m.kalinin
content: now i am thinking about the case when attestation is included into a competing fork which doesn't know about a blockroot while the checkpoint is known

author: m.kalinin
content: it isn't possible to process an attestation in this case unless a checkpoint root is explicitly included

author: potuz
content: yes, processing of attestations would have to be different, but it's not clear to me that we care about this on-chain component, as long as the off-chain component in forkchoice is fine it's not clear to me the impact of the on-chain part
